utterances: And I'm Michele Norris.
The spinach tainted with E.
coli has been traced to a company in Northern California.
But spinach growers in Southern California, where most of the crop is grown in the winter months, are worried that demand for their product will take a dive as consumers stay away.
In fact, some growers are wondering whether to plant the crop at all.
From member station KPBS in San Diego, Andrew Phelps reports.
The FDA says all spinach is safe now, but a deadly E.
coli outbreak can scare off consumers for years.
That's why Steve Birdsall, the Imperial County Agricultural Commissioner, is trying to get this message out.
Please continue to eat your vegetables and your leafy vegetables in particular.
Birdsall doesn't just want to promote a healthful diet.
In 2005, spinach was a $20 million crop in Imperial County.
That's 40 percent of the market.
Leafy vegetables in general generated $220 million here.
Farmer Jack Vessey is anxiously watching the sprinklers across a wide field of tilled soil.
Vessey strategizes daily with partners about how much spinach to plant this year on his ranch in Holtville.
You'll just hear a lot of uncertainty in our voices, apprehension, uncertainty.
When you plant a crop, you know, number one you want it to be harvested and sold and consumed.
And we don't plant crops just to sit in the field and not get harvested.
But that's exactly what he's worried about.
Vessey planted 16 acres of spinach this week.
He's probably the first local grower to plant any spinach so far this year.
The season normally starts next week.
But Vessey got an early order from a jittery customer who pulled out of Salinas, the origin of the E.
coli outbreak.
Still, Vessey is taking a gamble.
Come harvest time, his customer could get cold feet.
That could mean a loss of $50,000 for Vessey.
I'm still uncomfortable with what I'm seeing being watered right now, but my only comfort is they need to refill the pipeline.
Here in California's Imperial Valley and across the border in Yuma, Arizona, leafy vegetables thrive during the winter months.
It's too cold everywhere else.
Until spring of next year, this region is the nation's biggest producer of spinach.
It's a cash crop that growers have come to depend on for steady returns.
So this is one of my safer crops.
You know, we have a pretty good feeling.
We've been doing spinach long enough and we're planning - we believe we're going to make money, we're going to yield X amount and profit X amount.
But Vessey says this disaster took everyone by surprise.
In fact, growers here have been planting more spinach in recent years to meet rising demand.
Commissioner Birdsall says the crop grew by 35 percent between 2004 and 2005.
But now, he's worried about more than just spinach.
And then there's a significant and I think valid concern that this will carry over into people stop eating other leafy vegetables, which we grow down here.
So there could be like a domino effect, if you will.
(Speaking foreign language)
That's Rufina Artiaga, a Mexican worker on Vessey's ranch.
Artiaga says the spinach fears are on his mind, too.
He says the problem doesn't just hurt one person, it can hurt many.
(Speaking foreign language)
Artiaga is working here legally.
He brings home money to his family in Mexico, not far south of here.
Loss of the spinach crop may mean less work for Artiaga and the thousands of other field workers who depend on this valley for their livelihood.
It's tough to estimate the total economic loss for the valley if growers decide to hedge their spinach bets this year.
Growers say they may forego planting substitute crops to save the time and labor.
Vessey says there isn't an alternative crop worth the risk, and he's already invested a half-million dollars into the seeds, fertilizer and labor required for spinach.
Vessey and other growers may leave their fields barren and wait to see if the spinach market rebounds.
At this point, what happens to that market is in consumers' hands.
For NPR News, I'm Andrew Phelps.
Since last week, Donald Trump has been taking phone calls from foreign leaders around the world.
What he hasn't taken is advice from the State Department.
NPR's Michele Kelemen reports.
The transition office on the ground floor of the State Department has been quiet as Trump and his advisers remain in New York.
State Department spokesman John Kirby says officials here stand ready and willing to offer any briefing materials to the Trump team.
And it's not our place to inject ourselves into those decisions about who the president-elect is going to speak to and what they're going to discuss.
I mean those are his staff's decisions to make.
We of course, as the secretary has made clear to the entire department - we of course stand ready to assist the president-elect's team in any way that they deem fit.
And there were no contacts with either the Trump transition team or Japanese officials before today's meeting with Shinzo Abe.
The schedule for that was only made clear this morning, and that may have unsettled officials in Japan, a key U.S.
ally.
A quick call to the State Department by Trump's staff could have avoided any ruffled feathers, says a longtime U.S.
diplomat, Ronald Neumann.
It might well be useful if they had had the kind of knowledge that State could give them about Japanese sensitivities and protocol, but it wouldn't necessarily be normal at this early stage.
Those are papers that the State Department desperately hopes somebody in the administration will read before they start making policy decisions.
Whether they will read them is questionable.
The Lebanese army seems committed to do that.
Palestinian groups here have given them the tentative green light to do it, but it could cause turmoil in other Palestinian refugee camps.
So they'd been very hesitant.
And then the third issue is civilians.
The numbers are unclear, Palestinian groups say there are about 3,000, others say there are 8,000.

A Palestinian commander inside the camp said the day that he had gathered them all in one section of the camp, they were building a berm, he said, to keep themselves separated from the militants of Fatah al-Islam and to make sure that they don't try to join those civilians to get out of the camp when and if this is over.
Why have they not left?
Why are the civilians building themselves in?
There's a lot of reasons for that.
For one thing, as I said, Lebanese security services don't go into Palestinian refugee camps.
So if you commit a crime in Lebanon, you can hop in to one of those camps and you can hide out.
So there are people who are wanted who are inside the camp, they don't want to come out.
There has been looting inside this refugee camp since the vast population left.
So some, especially men in the family said, okay, wives and children out, but I'm going to stay here and protect my house.
These people are very poor.
To lose that is to lose everything.
And then for many of them, they were refugees from 1948.
They moved here from, or forced to move here from what was then Palestine.
They've been refugees once; they don't want to do it again.
There are the old and there are the infirmed who also can't be brought out.
And so that leaves the population who are at risk with this fighting.
And there were reports tonight that there were civilian casualties.
The army was not letting any of the ambulances into the camp to evacuate anybody.
NPR's Deborah Amos in Beirut.
Thank you.
Thank you.
In Mississippi, search-and-rescue crews are moving south toward the coastline, where Katrina did the most damage.
The mayor of Biloxi told a local newspaper, `This is our tsunami.'
Lea Stokes is spokeswoman with the Mississippi Emergency Management Agency.
She joins us from Jackson.
Ms.
Stokes, what can you tell us about the extent of damage that you've found along the coast?
Well, this is obviously a very devastating, catastrophic event for both Louisiana residents and our own Mississippi residents and especially our Mississippi Gulf Coast.
We're still doing search-and-rescue missions.
We have one major highway that's been able to be cleared for first-responders and rescuers to get there and do their jobs.

And we're having to ask people to please don't return to their homes and don't try to be on that road because that one road is our only, really, link to the area that's hardest hit and to get crews and food and water and supplies and manpower to the area.
Which road is that that's still open?
That is Highway 49, which runs from the Mississippi Gulf Coast up through Hattiesburg and then eventually to the Jackson area.
What have you heard about how much is left of these communities along the coast?
I've heard that there are some communities along the coast that are not there.
Just not there at all.
Not there.
I've heard that parts of some of the major roads--Highway 90, which runs right along our beach--part of that road's not there.
And which communities is it that apparently have disappeared?
You know, we're hearing several things, and I don't know anything definite.
And since we have so many evacuees who are still out of the state and people who have families in those areas, I don't want to be specific because we don't know for sure.
There seemed to have been a number of people who did not evacuate in these communities along the coast, and I'm wondering if they had enough warning.
Your boss, Robert Latham, over the weekend was warning that he wasn't seeing enough preparedness, wasn't seeing signs that people were leaving, were heading north.
Right.
On Saturday, the evacuation numbers were very low.
On Sunday, they did start to pick up.
Local officials did issue mandatory and voluntary evacuations all along our Gulf Coast and even counties north of there.
And, of course, we know several hundred thousand people from both the New Orleans area and Mississippi did evacuate or they did go to higher grounds.
Is there some sense that maybe those evacuation orders came too late, that people thought they didn't have to take this too seriously?
